lm317.title: Calculator
lm317.description: Calculate output voltage or required resistors for LM317 voltage regulator.

howItWorks.title: How the LM317 Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: The LM317 is an adjustable linear voltage regulator that uses two external resistors to set the output voltage. It maintains a constant 1.25V reference between the output and adjust pins.
steps: Enter your desired output voltage (1.25V to 37V)
Set R1 value (typically 240Ω for optimal stability)
The calculator computes the required R2 value
Select the nearest standard resistor value

seoTips: Use R1 = 240Ω for optimal stability
Add filter capacitors at input and output
Ensure input voltage is at least 3V higher than output
Use a heatsink for high current applications
commonMistakes: Forgetting filter capacitors causing oscillation
Not accounting for minimum dropout voltage
Exceeding maximum current rating (1.5A)
Neglecting heat dissipation in high-power applications

faqs.question: What is the minimum output voltage from LM317?
faqs.answer: The minimum is 1.25V, which is the internal reference voltage of the regulator.

faqs.question: Why is 240Ω used for R1?
faqs.answer: 240Ω provides an optimal adjust pin current (about 5mA) that ensures regulator stability with low power consumption.

faqs.question: How do I calculate power dissipation in LM317?
faqs.answer: Power = (Vin - Vout) × Iout. Ensure you don't exceed maximum power and use an appropriate heatsink.

howItWorks.title: How Ohm's Law Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: V = I × R, P = V × I
howItWorks.explanation: Ohm's Law is the foundation of electrical engineering, describing the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance. Voltage equals current times resistance, and power equals voltage times current.

Enter the two known values
The calculator automatically computes the unknown value

seoTips: Remember Ohm's Law only applies to linear circuits
Use consistent units (Volts, Amps, Ohms)
Power in Watts helps select properly rated components
Calculate power to avoid exceeding component ratings
commonMistakes: Mixing units (milliamps instead of amps)
Applying Ohm's Law to non-linear components
Neglecting power dissipation calculations
Not accounting for temperature effects on resistance

faqs.question: What's the difference between voltage and current?
faqs.answer: Voltage is the electrical pressure difference (like water pressure), while current is the flow of electrons (like water flow rate). Resistance limits this flow.

faqs.question: Can I use Ohm's Law for AC circuits?
faqs.answer: Yes, but for AC circuits with inductors or capacitors, use impedance (Z) instead of resistance (R).

faqs.question: How do I calculate resistance if I only know power and voltage?
faqs.answer: Use the formula R = V²/P. For example: a 60W bulb at 220V has R = 220²/60 = 807Ω.

Verify resistor power ratings to prevent burnout
commonMistakes: Ignoring load resistance effect on output voltage
Using resistors too low causing high power consumption
Not accounting for resistor tolerance in calculations
Using voltage dividers for high current applications

faqs.question: Can I use a voltage divider as a voltage regulator?
faqs.answer: Not recommended because output voltage changes with load. Use a regulator like LM317 for varying loads.

faqs.question: How do I choose appropriate resistor values?
faqs.answer: Choose resistors so that divider current is at least 10x expected load current to minimize load effect.

faqs.question: Does a voltage divider work with AC?
faqs.answer: Yes, but use impedance instead of resistance if there are capacitors or inductors in the circuit.

Using wrong LED voltage (varies by color)
Connecting parallel LEDs with a single resistor
Not accounting for resistor power rating (Watts)

faqs.question: Why does LED voltage vary by color?
faqs.answer: Forward voltage depends on semiconductor material. Blue and white LEDs use materials with higher bandgap energy, requiring higher voltage.

faqs.question: What happens if I use a smaller resistor than needed?
faqs.answer: Higher current flows through the LED, reducing its lifespan or burning it instantly. Always use equal or higher resistance.

faqs.question: Can I connect multiple LEDs in series?
faqs.answer: Yes, but ensure total LED voltages are at least 2-3V less than supply voltage for the resistor to work properly.

howItWorks.explanation: Resistors use colored bands to indicate their resistance value. Each color represents a digit (0-9), a multiplier (power of 10), or a tolerance percentage. Reading bands left to right gives the resistance value.

seoTips: 4-band: 2 digits + multiplier + tolerance
5-band: 3 digits + multiplier + tolerance (precision resistors)
Gold multiplier = 0.1, Silver multiplier = 0.01
Tolerance: Gold = 5%, Silver = 10%, Brown = 1%
commonMistakes: Reading bands in wrong direction (start from the side with bands closer together)
Confusing brown and red, or orange and yellow
Mixing up gold/silver tolerance vs. multiplier bands
Not accounting for tolerance when selecting resistors

faqs.question: How do I know which end to start reading from?
faqs.answer: Start from the end with bands grouped closer together. The tolerance band (gold/silver) is usually slightly separated and read last.

faqs.question: What's the difference between 4-band and 5-band resistors?
faqs.answer: 5-band resistors have an extra significant digit, providing higher precision (e.g., 1% tolerance) compared to 4-band resistors (typically 5% or 10%).

faqs.question: Why do some resistors have no tolerance band?
faqs.answer: No tolerance band indicates 20% tolerance. These are older or very inexpensive resistors rarely used in precision applications.

faqs.question: What is a kWh?
faqs.answer: A kilowatt-hour (kWh) is a unit of energy equal to using 1000 watts for one hour. A 100W bulb running for 10 hours uses 1 kWh.

faqs.question: Why does my actual bill differ from the estimate?
faqs.answer: Actual bills may include tiered pricing (higher rates for higher consumption), demand charges, fuel adjustments, and various fees not included in simple calculations.

faqs.question: How can I reduce my electricity bill?
faqs.answer: Use energy-efficient appliances, LED lighting, smart thermostats, and unplug devices when not in use. Consider solar panels for long-term savings.

faqs.question: What is AWG?
faqs.answer: American Wire Gauge (AWG) is a standardized wire sizing system. Lower numbers indicate thicker wires with higher current capacity. Each 3-gauge decrease doubles the cross-sectional area.

faqs.question: Why does distance matter for wire sizing?
faqs.answer: Longer distances increase resistance, causing voltage drop. Excessive voltage drop can cause equipment malfunction and energy waste.

faqs.question: When should I use aluminum instead of copper?
faqs.answer: Aluminum is cheaper and lighter, suitable for long runs and high-current applications. However, it requires one AWG size larger and special connectors to prevent oxidation issues.

Not accounting for surrounding objects affecting performance
Building antennas too close to metal structures
Confusing electrical length with physical length

faqs.question: What is velocity factor?
faqs.answer: Velocity factor accounts for the slower propagation of signals in conductors compared to free space. Copper wire has a velocity factor of about 0.95, meaning the physical antenna is 5% shorter than the theoretical length.

faqs.question: Why are dipoles half-wavelength?
faqs.answer: A half-wave dipole creates an efficient radiation pattern and provides a good impedance match (around 73 ohms) to common transmission lines.

faqs.question: Can I use any wire for antenna construction?
faqs.answer: Yes, but copper wire is preferred for its conductivity. The wire gauge affects antenna bandwidth - thicker wire provides wider bandwidth.

resonance.title: Resonance Calculator

howItWorks.title: How the Resonance Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: Calculates the resonant frequency where inductive and capacitive reactances are equal and cancel out. At resonance, the circuit exhibits minimum impedance (series) or maximum impedance (parallel).
steps: Enter the inductance value (L)
Enter the capacitance value (C)
Enter resistance for Q factor calculation
View resonant frequency, Q factor, and bandwidth

seoTips: Higher Q factor means narrower bandwidth and sharper selectivity
Series RLC: minimum impedance at resonance
Parallel RLC: maximum impedance at resonance
Q > 10 is considered high-Q (good selectivity)
commonMistakes: Confusing series and parallel resonance behavior
Ignoring component tolerances affecting resonant frequency
Not accounting for parasitic resistance in inductors
Using components outside their rated frequency range

faqs.question: What is the Q factor?
faqs.answer: Quality factor (Q) measures how 'sharp' the resonance is. Higher Q means the circuit is more selective and has less energy loss. Q = f₀/BW, where BW is the 3dB bandwidth.

faqs.question: What happens at resonance?
faqs.answer: At resonance, XL = XC, so they cancel. In series RLC, impedance equals R (minimum). In parallel RLC, impedance is maximum. Current and voltage are in phase.

faqs.question: How do I increase the Q factor?
faqs.answer: Use lower-resistance inductors, higher-quality capacitors, and minimize parasitic losses. Increasing L/C ratio while maintaining the same resonant frequency also increases Q.

faqs.question: What is the Peukert effect?
faqs.answer: The Peukert effect describes how battery capacity decreases at higher discharge rates. A battery rated at 100Ah at 5A discharge might only deliver 80Ah at 20A discharge.

faqs.question: Why should I use efficiency percentage?
faqs.answer: No power conversion is 100% efficient. Voltage regulators, DC-DC converters, and internal battery resistance all consume power. 85% efficiency is a good estimate for most applications.

faqs.question: How do mAh and Ah relate?
faqs.answer: 1 Ah = 1000 mAh. Small batteries (phone, Arduino) use mAh, while larger batteries (car, solar) use Ah. Multiply Ah by voltage to get Wh (energy capacity).

seoTips: Energy stored is proportional to current squared

commonMistakes: Ignoring inductor saturation current limits
Forgetting DC resistance losses
Not considering core material frequency limits
Using inductors beyond their self-resonant frequency

faqs.question: Why does energy depend on current squared?
faqs.answer: The magnetic field energy is proportional to the square of the magnetic flux, which is proportional to current. Doubling current quadruples the stored energy.

faqs.question: What is inductor saturation?
faqs.answer: Saturation occurs when the core material cannot hold more magnetic flux. Above the saturation current, inductance drops dramatically, reducing energy storage and potentially causing circuit failure.

faqs.question: How do I choose between air-core and ferrite-core inductors?
faqs.answer: Air-core inductors have no saturation but lower inductance. Ferrite cores provide higher inductance in smaller packages but saturate at specific current levels. Choose based on current requirements and frequency.

reactance.title: Reactance Calculator
reactance.description: Calculate inductive or capacitive reactance in AC circuits.
reactance.footer_note: Reactance values are for ideal components at the specified frequency.

howItWorks.title: How the Reactance Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: Calculates the opposition to AC current flow from inductors and capacitors. Inductive reactance increases with frequency, while capacitive reactance decreases with frequency.
steps: Select reactance type (inductive or capacitive)
Enter the component value (L or C)
Enter the AC frequency
View the calculated reactance in ohms

seoTips: Inductive reactance: XL = 2πfL (increases with frequency)
Capacitive reactance: XC = 1/(2πfC) (decreases with frequency)
At resonance, XL = XC
Reactance is measured in ohms like resistance
commonMistakes: Confusing reactance with impedance (Z includes R)
Forgetting the negative sign for capacitive reactance in calculations
Using DC component values at high frequencies
Not converting units (mH to H, µF to F)

faqs.question: What is the difference between reactance and impedance?
faqs.answer: Reactance (X) is opposition from inductors or capacitors only. Impedance (Z) combines resistance and reactance: Z = √(R² + X²).

faqs.question: Why does inductive reactance increase with frequency?
faqs.answer: Higher frequencies mean faster current changes. Inductors oppose current changes, so faster changes create more opposition (higher reactance).

faqs.question: Why is capacitive reactance negative in some formulas?
faqs.answer: The negative sign indicates the phase relationship - capacitive current leads voltage by 90°, while inductive current lags. This matters when calculating total impedance.

Forgetting power factor in power calculations
Assuming unbalanced loads follow balanced formulas

faqs.question: What is the difference between star and delta connections?
faqs.answer: In star (Y), each phase connects to a common neutral point. In delta (Δ), phases connect end-to-end forming a triangle. Star provides neutral access; delta provides higher current capacity.

faqs.question: Why is three-phase more efficient than single-phase?
faqs.answer: Three-phase delivers constant power (no zero crossings), uses less copper for the same power, and produces rotating magnetic fields directly for motors.

faqs.question: When should I use star vs. delta?
faqs.answer: Star is common for distribution with neutral access and lower phase voltage. Delta is used for high-current loads and motors that need to start with reduced voltage (star-delta starter).

faqs.question: Why use series resistors?
faqs.answer: Series resistors increase total resistance and divide voltage proportionally. Useful for voltage dividers, current limiting, and creating specific resistance values.

faqs.question: Why use parallel resistors?
faqs.answer: Parallel resistors decrease total resistance, increase current capacity, and provide redundancy. If one fails, the circuit may still work.

faqs.question: How do I analyze a circuit with both series and parallel?
faqs.answer: Simplify step by step: first combine parallel groups into single equivalents, then add series resistances. Repeat until you have one equivalent resistance.

faqs.question: Why is voltage drop important?
faqs.answer: Excessive voltage drop causes dim lights, slow motors, and equipment damage. It also wastes energy as heat in the wires. Codes limit drop to 3-5%.

faqs.question: How can I reduce voltage drop?
faqs.answer: Use larger wire gauge, shorter cable runs, copper instead of aluminum, or higher system voltage. For DC systems, consider running at higher voltage then converting down.

faqs.question: Does voltage drop affect power loss?
faqs.answer: Yes, power loss = I² × R. The lost power becomes heat in the cable. Higher currents have disproportionately higher losses due to the squared relationship.

faqs.question: What is IPC-2221?
faqs.answer: IPC-2221 is the generic standard for printed circuit board design. It provides formulas and guidelines for trace sizing, clearances, and thermal management.

faqs.question: Why do internal traces need to be wider?
faqs.answer: Internal traces are surrounded by PCB material that insulates heat. External traces can dissipate heat to air, so they can carry more current for the same width.

faqs.question: How does copper thickness affect trace width?
faqs.answer: Thicker copper (2oz vs 1oz) can carry more current for the same width. Doubling copper thickness roughly allows 40% more current, not double.

faqs.question: What are peak sun hours?
faqs.answer: Peak sun hours (PSH) are equivalent hours of 1000W/m² solar irradiance. 5 PSH means the total daily energy equals 5 hours of full sun, not actual sunlight duration.

faqs.question: How do I determine my daily consumption?
faqs.answer: Add up wattage × hours of use for all appliances. Check energy bills for monthly kWh and divide by 30. Use a power meter for accurate measurements.

faqs.question: What system voltage should I choose?
faqs.answer: 12V for small systems under 2kW, 24V for medium systems, 48V for larger systems. Higher voltage reduces current and cable losses but requires more panels in series.

faqs.question: What is the difference between inverting and non-inverting?
faqs.answer: Inverting amplifier flips signal polarity (180° phase shift) with input impedance R1. Non-inverting maintains polarity with very high input impedance. Gain formulas differ.

faqs.question: Why is there a negative sign in inverting gain?
faqs.answer: The negative sign indicates phase inversion - when input goes positive, output goes negative. The magnitude |Av| = R2/R1 is the voltage amplification.

faqs.question: What happens if calculated output exceeds supply voltage?
faqs.answer: The output saturates near the supply rails (typically 1-2V below). Use rail-to-rail op-amps or ensure gain keeps output within linear range.

faqs.question: Why can't I get 50% duty cycle in astable mode?
faqs.answer: Standard 555 charges through R1+R2 but discharges only through R2, so high time is always longer than low time. Use a diode across R2 or use a 556 dual timer for 50% duty.

faqs.question: What is monostable mode used for?
faqs.answer: Monostable (one-shot) produces a single pulse of precise duration when triggered. Used for debouncing, missing pulse detection, and creating time delays.

faqs.question: What is the difference between 555 and 7555?
faqs.answer: The 7555 (CMOS version) has lower power consumption, wider voltage range (2-15V), higher input impedance, and faster switching. Better for battery-powered and precision applications.

faqs.question: What is power factor?
faqs.answer: Power factor (PF = cos φ) is the ratio of active power to apparent power. PF = 1 means all power is useful; lower PF means reactive power is wasted in the system.

faqs.question: What is the difference between XL and XC?
faqs.answer: XL (inductive reactance) increases with frequency, while XC (capacitive reactance) decreases. They have opposite phase effects, so they partially cancel in series circuits.

faqs.question: What happens at resonance in an RLC circuit?
faqs.answer: At resonance, XL = XC so they cancel. Total impedance equals R only (minimum for series, maximum for parallel). Current is maximum and in phase with voltage.

faqs.question: What is the difference between kW and kVA?
faqs.answer: kW (kilowatts) is active/real power that does work. kVA (kilovolt-amperes) is apparent power including reactive components. kW = kVA × Power Factor.

faqs.question: Why does power factor matter?
faqs.answer: Low power factor means more current is needed for the same useful power, causing larger cables, higher losses, and potential utility penalties for industrial customers.

faqs.question: How do I calculate energy cost?
faqs.answer: Energy (kWh) = Power (kW) × Time (hours). Cost = kWh × rate. For example, 2kW × 5 hours = 10 kWh. At $0.10/kWh, cost = $1.00.

Ignoring capacitor voltage and frequency ratings

faqs.question: Why do I need power factor correction?
faqs.answer: Low PF means drawing more current than needed, causing higher cable losses, larger equipment sizing, and utility penalties. Correction saves money and improves efficiency.

faqs.question: What happens if I over-correct power factor?
faqs.answer: Over-correction creates a leading power factor, which can cause voltage rise, resonance with system inductance, and potential equipment damage. Stay below 0.98 PF.

faqs.question: Should I use fixed or automatic capacitor banks?
faqs.answer: Fixed capacitors work for constant loads. Automatic banks with contactors switch capacitor stages based on measured PF, ideal for varying loads like factories.

faqs.question: What is the difference between VA and Watts in transformers?
faqs.answer: VA (volt-amperes) is apparent power - what the transformer delivers. Watts is active power after accounting for power factor. For resistive loads, VA = Watts.

faqs.question: Why does efficiency matter?
faqs.answer: Transformer losses become heat. Lower efficiency means more energy wasted, higher operating costs, and potential overheating. Modern transformers achieve 95-99% efficiency.

faqs.question: Can I use a transformer with DC?
faqs.answer: No, transformers only work with AC. DC creates a constant magnetic field that induces no voltage. Use a DC-DC converter or first convert DC to AC.

faqs.question: What is diversity factor?
faqs.answer: Diversity factor accounts for loads not running simultaneously. A home might have 30kW of loads but only 15kW peak demand. Diversity = Peak / Total, typically 0.4-0.8.

faqs.question: How do I size the main breaker?
faqs.answer: Calculate total demand with diversity factor, add 25% for continuous loads, then select next standard breaker size up. Always follow local electrical codes.

faqs.question: What cable size do I need?
faqs.answer: Cable size depends on current, distance, and installation method. Use ampacity tables from NEC/IEC, derate for temperature and bundling, and check voltage drop.

faqs.question: Why do motors have high inrush current?
faqs.answer: At startup, motor speed is zero so there is no back-EMF to oppose current. The motor acts like a short circuit until it accelerates, drawing 6-8x rated current.

faqs.question: How do I reduce inrush current?
faqs.answer: Use soft starters (reduced voltage), VFDs (variable frequency drives), star-delta starters for motors, or NTC thermistors/resistors for capacitive loads.

faqs.question: What type of circuit breaker handles inrush?
faqs.answer: Use Type C or D breakers for motor/transformer loads. Type B trips at 3-5x, Type C at 5-10x, and Type D at 10-20x rated current.

faqs.question: What is capacitor ESR?
faqs.answer: Equivalent Series Resistance (ESR) is the internal resistance of a capacitor. High ESR causes heating and reduces filtering effectiveness, especially at high frequencies.

faqs.question: Why does energy depend on voltage squared?
faqs.answer: Capacitor energy E = ½CV². Doubling voltage quadruples energy storage. This is why high-voltage capacitors in flash circuits store significant energy.

faqs.question: What voltage rating should I choose?
faqs.answer: Select a capacitor rated at least 20-50% above your working voltage. Operating near the limit reduces lifespan and reliability, especially for electrolytics.

faqs.question: Why is there a factor of 10 vs 20 in dB formulas?
faqs.answer: Power uses 10× because dB was defined for power ratios. Voltage/current uses 20× because P = V²/R, so power ratio = voltage ratio squared. Log of square = 2× log.

faqs.question: What does negative dB mean?
faqs.answer: Negative dB indicates attenuation (signal loss). -3 dB means half the power, -6 dB means quarter power. Negative values mean the output is smaller than input.

faqs.question: What is the difference between dB and dBm?
faqs.answer: dB is a ratio (unitless). dBm is absolute power relative to 1 milliwatt. 0 dBm = 1 mW, +10 dBm = 10 mW, +30 dBm = 1 W.

faqs.question: What is the difference between frequency and angular frequency?
faqs.answer: Frequency (f) is cycles per second in Hz. Angular frequency (ω) is radians per second = 2πf. Angular frequency is used in AC circuit analysis and phasor calculations.

faqs.question: How does wavelength change in different media?
faqs.answer: Wavelength = velocity/frequency. In materials, wave velocity is slower than in vacuum, so wavelength is shorter. This is why fiber optic cables have velocity factor < 1.

faqs.question: What frequency range is audible?
faqs.answer: Humans hear approximately 20 Hz to 20 kHz. Below 20 Hz is infrasound, above 20 kHz is ultrasound. Radio frequencies start around 3 kHz and extend to 300 GHz.

faqs.question: What is the difference between impedance and resistance?
faqs.answer: Resistance opposes DC and AC equally. Impedance includes resistance plus reactance (from inductors/capacitors). Z = R for purely resistive circuits; Z = √(R² + X²) otherwise.

faqs.question: Why does phase angle matter?
faqs.answer: Phase angle determines power factor (cos φ). At 0°, all power is useful. At 90°, no real power is delivered - it just oscillates. Phase angle affects circuit efficiency.

faqs.question: How do I use impedance for power calculations?
faqs.answer: Power = V²/Z × cos(φ) or I²Z × cos(φ). The cos(φ) term is the power factor. Only the resistive component of impedance dissipates real power.

faqs.question: What is motor efficiency?
faqs.answer: Efficiency is the ratio of mechanical output power to electrical input power. A 90% efficient motor drawing 10 kW delivers 9 kW of mechanical power; 1 kW becomes heat.

faqs.question: Why do motors have low power factor?
faqs.answer: Motors are inductive loads that require magnetizing current to create the magnetic field. This reactive current doesn't do useful work but still flows, lowering power factor.

faqs.question: How do I convert HP to kW?
faqs.answer: Multiply HP by 0.746 to get kW. For example, 10 HP = 7.46 kW mechanical output. To find electrical input, divide by efficiency: 7.46 / 0.90 = 8.29 kW input.
